Introduction

Urethral injuries are uncommon and involve partial or complete disruption of the urethra.  These injuries are typically classified as anterior or posterior based on the anatomic segment involved.  Common etiologies include pelvic fractures, perineal trauma, and direct penile injury.  Patients classically have blood at the urethral meatus, perineal bruising, an inability to void, and a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination.

Pathogenesis



The male urethra is anatomically divided into 2 segments: the anterior urethra, which includes the penile and bulbar segments, and the posterior urethra, which includes the membranous and prostatic segments (

figure 1
).  Urethral injuries are similarly classified according to the segment involved.

Anterior urethral injury



The anterior urethra is protected from indirect forces by its relative mobility.  It is typically injured secondary to instrumentation (eg, catheterization) or direct blunt force trauma (eg, straddle injury, penile fracture) (

figure 2
).  Anterior injuries commonly involve contusions or partial tears; complete disruptions are less frequent.

Posterior urethral injury



The posterior urethra is anchored to the pelvic bones by supportive structures, including the urogenital diaphragm and the puboprostatic ligament.  Traumatic pelvic fractures can result in the upward displacement of these structures, leading to excessive stretching and tearing of the membranous urethra, most commonly at the bulbomembranous junction (the transition point between the anterior and posterior urethra) (

figure 3
).  In contrast, the prostatic urethra is relatively protected due to its encasement within the prostate gland and is therefore less frequently injured.

Risk factors



  • Male sex:  Due to the presence of a longer, exposed urethra.  Urethral injuries in female patients are extremely rare.
  • Pelvic fractures:  Most common cause of posterior urethral injuries.
  • Improper or traumatic catheter insertion.
  • External blunt trauma to the perineum or pelvis (eg, straddle injury, animal bites, penile fracture, gunshot/stab wound).
  • Pelvic or urologic surgery.

Clinical presentation



The typical clinical manifestations of a urethral injury include:



  • Blood at the urethral meatus (highly suggestive sign).
  • Difficulty voiding or inability to void.
  • Hematuria (gross or microscopic).
  • Perineal or scrotal ecchymosis.
  • High-riding prostate on digital rectal examination (posterior injury):  Tearing at the bulbomembranous junction allows urine and blood to extravasate into the potential spaces under the prostate and bladder, displacing them superiorly.

Differential diagnosis



  • Bladder rupture:  Usually occurs following blunt abdominal trauma or pelvic fractures.  It typically presents with suprapubic tenderness, gross hematuria, and difficulty voiding; however, perineal bruising, a high-riding prostate, and blood at the urethral meatus are not characteristic.
  • Urethral stricture:  Often results as a delayed complication of prior urethral trauma; symptoms develop gradually over time and include progressive, painless difficulty with voiding.  Bruising and bleeding are not typically seen.
  • Scrotal hematoma:  Results from blunt trauma to the scrotum or perineum, leading to scrotal swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness.  Voiding is usually unaffected, and there is no blood at the urethral meatus unless a concurrent urethral injury is present.

Diagnosis



Male patients with external genital trauma should undergo a systematic examination of all genital structures.  Further evaluation for urethral injury is warranted if any of the following findings are present: blood at the urethral meatus, hematuria, difficulty voiding, perineal bruising, or a high-riding prostate.

Laboratory evaluation



Although laboratory testing cannot confirm urethral injury, the following tests are typically obtained during the evaluation:



  • Urinalysis:  Shows microscopic (and gross) hematuria.
  • Complete blood count:  Evaluates for anemia related to posttraumatic hemorrhage.
  • Electrolytes, renal function, and coagulation studies:  Necessary for preoperative preparation (if urgent repair is indicated).

Imaging studies



All patients with suspected urethral injury should undergo retrograde urethrogram (RUG), the gold standard for diagnosis.  This diagnostic test involves an x-ray of the urethral tract following injection of radiopaque contrast through the urethral meatus.  Extravasation of contrast from the urethra is diagnostic of urethral injury (

image 1
).



Urethrography should be performed before urethral (eg, Foley) catheterization, which can worsen the injury, potentially converting a partial urethral tear into a complete urethral laceration.



Additional imaging may be warranted based on the mechanism of traumatic injury.  This may include a pelvic x-ray to evaluate for pelvic fractures and a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to assess for intraabdominal injuries, such as bladder trauma.

Management



Confirmation of a urethral injury requires immediate urologic consultation.  Management typically includes bladder decompression and immediate or delayed surgical repair of the urethra.

Bladder decompression



Bladder decompression is essential in urethral injuries to prevent urinary extravasation into surrounding tissues, which can result in inflammation, infection, and abscess formation.  In addition, when the urethra is swollen, obstructed by hematoma, or transected, the bladder is unable to empty effectively, leading to overdistension and urinary outflow obstruction.



In cases of complete urethral disruption, a suprapubic catheter should be placed for urinary diversion.  Partial disruptions may be managed with gentle urethral catheterization, ideally performed under fluoroscopic or endoscopic guidance; any resistance to urethral catheter placement warrants suprapubic placement to avoid further injury.

Definitive management



  • Anterior urethral injury:  Penetrating anterior urethral injuries, or those involving open wounds, persistent bleeding, or complete transection, typically require urgent surgical repair.  In contrast, urethral contusions or partial urethral disruptions may be managed conservatively with urethral catheter placement (under visual guidance) or suprapubic catheterization, followed by delayed repair.  Some injuries may heal spontaneously, but most require surgery.
  • Posterior urethral injury:  Most posterior urethral injuries are managed with urinary diversion and surgical repair after 3-6 months.  This allows the inflammation and tissue edema from associated pelvic trauma to resolve, making the repair less complex.

Prognosis



Urethral injuries are typically not life-threatening, although they may occur alongside other potentially life-threatening traumatic injuries.  With appropriate management, most patients achieve favorable functional outcomes.  However, long-term complications can include urethral stricture (due to scarring), erectile dysfunction (particularly in posterior injuries), and urinary incontinence.

Summary



Urethral injuries typically result from trauma to the genital or perineal region and are classified as anterior or posterior based on the anatomic area involved.  Classic signs include blood at the urethral meatus, hematuria, difficulty voiding, perineal bruising, and/or a high-riding prostate on digital rectal examination.  Retrograde urethrography is the gold standard for diagnosis.  Management focuses on urinary diversion and surgical repair, which may be delayed or performed immediately depending on the severity and location of the injury.
